name: Episode V - The IOC Strikes Back

agents.name: IOC Submission Webform
agents.description: A security analyst can submit Indicators of Compromise to check the disposition

agents.name: Search for IP Address
agents.description:
Search for an IP Address in VirusTotal. Report returns asn information, download samples, resolutions, detected and undetected urls etc.

Link to documentation: https://virustotal.readme.io/reference/ip-info

agents.name: Search for IP address
agents.description:
Find archived scans on urlscan.io by IPv4 or IPv6, either using an exact IP or a subnet definition. API search will find public scans performed by anyone as well as unlisted and private scans performed by you or your teams. 

URLscan.io query uses ElasticSearch syntax. This template allows you to search by any field supported by the search reference. To see all searchable fields, see the search API reference.

Link to search API reference: https://urlscan.io/docs/search/
Link to documentation: https://urlscan.io/docs/api/

local.final_payload:
=REJECT(
  LOCAL.optional_parameters,
  LAMBDA(
    item,
    OR(
      item = NULL,
      IF(
        OR(
          TYPE(item) = "TrueClass",
          TYPE(item) = "FalseClass",
          TYPE(item) = "Integer"
        ),
        IS_EMPTY(TEXT(item)),
        IS_EMPTY(item)
      )
    )
  )
)

agents.name: Redirect Back to IOC Submission Page
Convert Whois Date with AI Automatic Mode

options.guidance: Convert time to Pacific Standard Time in the format YYYY-MM-DD.
options.script:
import datetime
import pytz

def main(input: int) -> str:
    """
    Convert the given Unix timestamp to Pacific Standard Time (PST) and return the date in YYYY-MM-DD format.
    """
    pst = pytz.timezone('US/Pacific')
    dt = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(input, tz=pst)
    return dt.strftime('%Y-%m-%d')

agents.name: Analyze alert
agents.description: Analyze an incoming security alert and make recommendations.

options.prompt:
Act as an expert cybersecurity engineer analyzing the following alert. Respond with some recommended actions for handling the alert, along with a risk rating from 0-10 and explanation. 


Respond with JSON with 3 fields: "recommendations", "risk_rating" and "risk_explanation". Only use data from the event, do not generate any example data or make any assumptions.

Event data:
<<data_example.details>>

diagram_notes.content:
# Goals
- Learn how to construct a Tines Page for submitting IOCs
- Learn about Extract Mode & the MAP function to parse a csv.
- Learn how to search Tines Template library to use preconfigure Tines Actions, such as searching an IP address in VirusTotal & URLScan.io.
- Learn about the Tines AI action.
- Learn about the Send To Story action/webhooks
Helpful Regex for checking the validity of domain, ipv4, and sha256 IOCs
# Exercise 3 - Build your own Tines webform for IOC submission or for searching the Star Wars API.
# AI LLM To Analyze Alerts to determine which need follow up

# Requirements
-  Sign up for a free personal API key at VirusTotal and URLScan.io.

# [Download IOCs CSV from my GitHub repo](https://github.com/AutomateSecOps/BCNet-2025/tree/main/iocs)
# [Tines Date Function](https://www.tines.com/docs/formulas/functions/date/)

# [Tines Map Function](https://www.tines.com/docs/formulas/functions/map/)

# [Tines CSV Parse To Objects Function](https://www.tines.com/docs/formulas/functions/csv-parse-to-objects/)

# [Tines Base64_Decode Function](https://www.tines.com/docs/formulas/functions/base64-decode/)

# [Tines Automatic Mode](https://www.tines.com/docs/actions/types/event-transformation/automatic/#example-configuration-options)

# [Tips for Automatic Mode](https://explained.tines.com/en/articles/9369122-tips-for-automatic-mode)

# [Troubleshooting Tips in Pages & HTTP Request action](https://explained.tines.com/en/articles/9889226-example-approach-story-troubleshooting)

fields.name: Paragraph
fields.content: Use the panel on the left to style and manage your page. Edit, sort, and delete page elements by selecting them on the page. And add new elements by dragging them from the left panel and onto the page.

action_inputs.name: Search after
action_inputs.description:
For retrieving the next batch of results, value of the 'sort' attribute of the last (oldest) result you received (comma-separated).

`JOIN(LAST(search_for_ip_address.body.results).sort, ",")`
